fields.description:
I'm successfully getting commit notification emails, and we're using smart commits so the first item a developer puts in the message is the Jira ticket #, and that is showing up with a successful link, however the remainder of the commit message is not showing up in the email so the email notification looks rather blank. I'm attaching a screenshot of the email, and of the actual commit.

This impacts us because we rely on reviewing the emails for proper commit messages to know what happened in a commit, and we can't rely on that. I don't see why the entire message doesn't appear in the email, despite any formatting issues.
fields.summary: As a committer, I would like the full commit message to be delivered in commit notifications

fields.description:
We've got a few repositories which keep "built" css and javascript files checked in.  We need to check these files in so our package manager ([component|https://github.com/component/component]) is able to access them at install-time, rather than forcing it to pre-process our stylesheets/templates (stylus, less, jade, whatever).

My request is that we can somehow tell the pull request view (https://bitbucket.org/user/repo/pull-request/XYZ/) to *not* display a diff on a few specific files.  This could be a setting at the "Create pull request" step, the repository settings panel.. anywhere, really.  This would make code reviews significantly easier and much faster.

An example repo structure would look like this:

{code}
$ tree
.
├── Makefile
├── Readme.md
├── cache.js
├── component.json
├── example.html
├── index.js
├── package.json
├── style.css # ignore diff
├── style.styl # show diff
├── template.jade # show diff
├── template.js # ignore diff
├── test
│   ├── cache.js
│   ├── generator.js
│   └── index.html
└── test-server.pid
{code}
fields.summary: Optionally disable diffs for specific files in a pull request
PHP nowdoc syntax not highlighted correctly

fields.description:
In a similar vein as BCLOUD-8054 (BB-9194), when a user adds an SSH key to a repository/user using an OAuth-authenticated application, that application's name/URL should be included in the notification e-mail.

Since the user will have recently authorized that application's access on the Bitbucket website, including the application name/link in the notification e-mail will help the user identify from where the new key originated, reducing surprise. If the user did not want that application to add an SSH key, the e-mail will tell the user which application to revoke in their account settings.
fields.summary: Include OAuth consumer in Add SSH Key e-mail if added by API (BB-11002)

fields.description:
In a similar vein as BCLOUD-8054 (BB-9194), including the label identifying an SSH Key would improve the usefulness of the automatic e-mails sent when new SSH keys are added to a repository/account.

Right now, the user who added the key and a snippet of the key contents are included, but when a key is added eg. via OAuth, the user might not have seen the public key contents before. Including the key label could make the new key notification less "scary"
fields.summary: Include key label in the Add SSH Key e-mail (BB-11001)

fields.description:
In git if you rename a file with "git mv" then it appears to understand that a file was renamed and will only show content changes when you do a "git diff".

It would be nice if the pull request diff view could understand this for file renames, currently it just shows the entire old filename as removed and the new filename as added, which is not very useful when trying to see a diff of a file that was renamed and changed slightly.

I can provide specific links to PR's in my team repo if you need some examples.

thanks!
fields.summary: Better support for file renames in pull request diff views

fields.description:
Trying to access private resources (repo, team, etc.) without permission, the response should be a 404 (Not Found), instead of a 403 (Forbidden).\\
The reasoning behind this suggestions is to preserve the privacy of the resources, since a 403 will confirm their existence, unlike a 404.
fields.summary: Accessing private resources without permissions should return a 404 (BB-4255)

fields.description:
We have a simple setup where developers on the team work on forks of the definitive repo in a company-owned account; then submit changes via pull request. The repos need to be private as it's not open source code.

The problem is while we can see the overall diff on PRs, we can't view individual commit diffs, which is a pain when PRs are updated.

Root cause is permissions: individuals can't inherit permissions due to the general problem described in comments at https://bitbucket.org/site/master/issue/4828/team-admins-dont-have-read-access-to-forks so everyone's fork is effectively locked down to one person.

When you inherit permissions for a repo, your account shouldn't have to have the same account level as the upstream repo. Alternatively, attach the commit diffs for the PR to the PR's permissions - ie. we can see the overall diff regardless of account settings, so the individual diffs could be revealed under the same scheme.
fields.summary: Can't view individual commits for team pull requests (BB-10999)

fields.description:
When creating a repository via the API with slug: label-test and name: label/test, the name of the created repository is "label-test" and not the expected "label/test"\\
I can create repositories via the bitbucket website as "label/test" without trouble; the slug is converted to "label-test" as expected and leaves the name intact.\\
Here is the full API request:

{code}
#!php

POST /2.0/repositories/LabelInteractive/label-sample
HTTP/1.1
Host: api.bitbucket.org
scm: git
name: label/sample
fork_policy: no_public_forks
is_private: 1
User-Agent: Guzzle/3.9.1 curl/7.30.0 PHP/5.5.9
{code}
fields.summary: API v2 converts non-ASCII characters in repo name to hyphen

fields.description:
Currently we are trying to use some private bitbucket repositories with the repo tool from google.\\
The problem is that bitbucket uses a colon (":") as the separator between the host and the organization. This leads to the situation that linux handles the organization name as service identifier which it tries to lookup. Even if it can successfully lookup this identifier (for example if you modify /etc/services) the portion of the repo url with the organization name is lost and git probably tries to connect the wrong port.\\
I can imagine since the colon has a reserved meaning in URLs that other tools will run into the same issues.\\
It would be nice if this gets fixed in the near future as this problem is currently a blocker for us.\\
Using the https URLs is no alternative since these are user specific for private repos.
fields.summary: Colon as separator between host and organization is invalid

fields.description: After pushing several updates on a branch that I had thought I already pushed to the server but apparently did not and then pushing the branch I found that the source page doesn't know that the branch exists even though when going directly to the /source/ link it states it's on the branch but when choosing the branch it states "The branch 'basic-db' does not exist.". And then after already loading the basic-db branch it then switched the selector to a commit hash instead of basic-db
fields.summary: Branch there but not? After pushing commits then branch.

fields.description:
Hello if you own a private repo and are watching it then transfer it to another account the only way to unwatch it is to grant yourself access to the repo through the other account then unwatch it then remove access. This is only a problem with private repos because you need access to it to unwatch it or else it will still show up in your profile feed and other places on your account.

My suggestion is that if it is a private repo when you transfer it you should automatically stop watching it. You wont see updates anymore anyways since you wont have access anymore.
fields.summary: Unwatch transfered private repo (BB-10994)

fields.description: When using a git flow style branching model of (master/develop/feature/hotfixes) when creating a pull request for merging a feature into develop, select branch that the pull request diverged from (generally develop), rather than "master" by default.

fields.description:
When you've added a third-party integration, it may be desirable to disable it for a period while not deleting it entirely.

There is a certain amount of overhead in signing into the third-party system, locating the endpoint URL and re-establishing the link; a simple on/off switch would a welcome addition.

A single switch to disable all integrations would also be a good stretch goal.
fields.summary: Add ability to mark web hooks as disabled (BB-10998)

fields.description: While reviewing the commit graph, I find it to be difficult to distinguish which branch is which. A legend would be very helpful for reading the graph.
